However, in celebration its CRANniversary ğŸˆ I thought ggraph deserved a roundup post of its own.1 Dispatches from a proud papa ğŸ‘¨ ggraph: A grammar of graphics for relational data The repo from whence it sprangâ€¦ More cool R viz-ness from @thomasp85 "ggraph" https://t.co/ncCKDHlQAx #rstats #dataviz #ggplot2 pic.

item.title: Git guides
item.description: A completely selfish collection of resources (in addition to the GitHub Guides, which are excellent) to turn to when I inevitably get myself into Git troubleâ€¦ Git pretty by Justin Hileman "Git pretty" by @bobthecow ğŸ™Œ flowchart to follow so @jimhester_ doesn't have to ğŸš’ rescue my ğŸ”¥ed repos!https://t.co/NFjIxOqZ03 #git #github pic.twitter.com/nQhhznmsog — Mara Averick (@dataandme) December 20, 2017 Excuse me, do you have a moment to talk about version control?

item.title: Docker-izing your work in R ğŸ³
item.description: Updated: 2018-08-19 I am decidedly a novice when it comes to any and all things Docker (which, incidentally, is why Iâ€™ve been reading these posts). But, since itâ€™s helpful for me to have all of these resources together in one place, I thought Iâ€™d share the love around.1 R Docker turorial for reproducible research. via rOpenSci Labs This is actually a series of 6 lessons put together at the rOpenSci unconf in 2016.

item.title: Keeping up with blogdown ğŸŒŸ
item.description: Updated: 2018-08-30 Iâ€™ve loved blogdown ğŸ“¦ for so long, that I was kind of shocked ğŸ˜± when I saw Yinui Xieâ€™s post, Announcing blogdown: Create Websites with R Markdown, on the RStudio blog just last month! Have people really been living without the magic âœ¨ of blogdown in their lives for so long?! If you are one of these people, then hopefully this post (which, yes, is really just a roundup of tweets) will inspire you to join in on the fun ğŸ‘¯.

item.title: ğŸ˜¸ purrr-ty posts
item.description: Updated: ğŸ“† 2018-10-06. ğŸ‰ğŸ±Â purrr-tiest cheat sheet Purrr royal decree (ok, Iâ€™ll stop with the ğŸ± puns now), the purrr ğŸ“¦ now has its very own official RStudio cheat sheet: Apply Functions Cheat Sheet The purrr package makes it easy to work with lists and functions. This cheatsheet will remind you how to manipulate lists with purrr as well as how to apply functions iteratively to each element of a list or vector.

item.title: RegEx resources
item.description: Updated: ğŸ“† 2018-04-06. Regular Expressions, RegEx, regexpsâ€“ call them what you like, but no matter how you slice it, theyâ€™re useful af. After all, data spelunking is all about patterns, and thatâ€™s precisely what regexps are for: (wo)manhandling patterns in strings. Good Sirs Wickham and Grolemund, in their masterful tome, r4ds, describe them thusly: They [regexps] take a little while to get your head around, but once you understand them, youâ€™ll find them extremely useful.

item.title: R workflow fun
item.description: I was excited to see Declutter your R workflow with tidy tools1, a preprint by Zev Ross, Hadley Wickham, and David Robinson, among the many excellent papers in the Practical Data Science for Stats PeerJ collection.2 Workflows, whether data-analysis-related or not, are never a one-size-fits-all matter of course. Among other things, the workflows here differ in scope (heck, one of them doesnâ€™t even use R). That said, thereâ€™s lots to be learned from the processes, mistakes, and hard-wrought wisdom ğŸ¦‰ of others.

item.title: tidyeval resource roundup
item.description: Updated: 2018-10-06 Though, naturally, the Honorable Professor Doctor Sir Lord General Hadley Wickhamâ€™s Programming with dplyr article is the ne plus ultra of getting oneself aquainted with the latest and greatest in tidyeval programming recipes, quoting, and quasiquotation; there are some other resources out there. After posting a link to Edwin Thoenâ€™s â­ï¸ Tidy evaluation, most common actions, I was asked if there were other tidyeval tutorials I knew of.
